Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test
Application_Facts: Applicant was 200 days short of the required 1095 days due to absences for caring for her sick mother
Remedy_Requested: Overturn the decision and grant citizenship
Court_Ruling: No error or bias found in the Citizenship Judge's application of the physical presence test
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misapplication of residency test by Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard: Physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed with the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Records of travel and periods of absence from Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation supporting reasons for absence (caring for sick mother)
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or re-evaluation of residency
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for 1095 days in the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of meeting physical presence requirement
Cause_Description: Applicant did not meet the minimum physical presence requirement under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Handling: Considered but found insufficient to excuse non-compliance with residency rule
Evidence_Issues: Absences not excused under regulatory exceptions
Evidence_Assessment: Travel records and personal circumstances reviewed
Decision_Rationale: The physical presence test is a valid interpretation of the law; no legal error or bias established
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of qualifying presence despite compassionate reasons
